sub_topic: Calculation of the ionization energy of atoms
message_1: What is the ionization energy of a hydrogen atom when the electron transition takes place from the n=2 energy level to the n=∞ energy level? Given that the ionization energy of a hydrogen atom in the ground state is 13.6 eV.
message_2:
The ionization energy of a hydrogen atom can be calculated using the formula:

Ionization energy = -13.6 eV * (1/n_final² - 1/n_initial²)

In this case, the electron is transitioning from the n=2 energy level to the n=∞ energy level. So, n_initial = 2 and n_final = ∞.

Ionization energy = -13.6 eV * (1/∞² - 1/2²)

Since 1/∞² is essentially zero:

Ionization energy = -13.6 eV * (0 - 1/4)

Ionization energy = -13.6 eV * (-1/4)

Ionization energy = 3.4 eV

So, the ionization energy of a hydrogen atom when the electron transition takes place from the n=2 energy level to the n=∞ energy level is 3.4 eV.
